9. g3 is more common, but no better according to John Shaw (The King's Gambit, Quality Press).
Counterattacking d4 since f4 can no longer be held.
10. Nb5 is more popular, and the move recommended by GameKnot's chess engine. Shaw does not think Nb5 is good for more than equality, as Black has the safer king and the better coordinated pieces.

Shaw gives this position as =/+, and his analysis does not include White's reply. Black's pieces are better coordinated than White's, and Black has a lead in development. Plus it appears that Black will be able to maintain the extra pawn for the moment. I don't like the computer's recommendation of 10...Be6, as it puts it in a precarious position. If 11. d5, Ne5 will suffice, but if 10.gxf4, Black has nothing better than 10...d5, which gives white a protected passed e-pawn.
